required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of the Accuracy of Telehealth Examination Versus Clinical Examination in the Detection of Rotator Cuff Tears
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of the Accuracy of Telehealth Examination Versus Clinical Examination in the Detection of Rotator Cuff Tears

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare how accurately a pseudo-telehealth shoulder examination diagnoses rotator cuff tears compared to a regular clinical examination. MRI is used as the gold standard.

primary_outcome.measure: Agreement with MRI findings as they pertain to presence or absence of a rotator cuff tear
primary_outcome.description: % of exams that agreed with the MRI findings

intervention.description: This is a pseudo telehealth clinical exam for patients presenting with shoulder pain
This is a standard in-person clinical exam for patients presenting with shoulder pain

study_pop.textblock: Patients over 40 with shoulder pain that can be MRIed

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 40 years of age or older, presenting with shoulder pain, and seen in the Duke Sports Medicine clinic by Dr. Wittstein or Dr. Lassiter
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient cannot have had prior shoulder arthroplasty, instability or history of fracture/dislocation. Pregnant women will be excluded from the study because there will be an MRI. Anyone unable or unwilling to have an MRI will be excluded from the study.

results_reference.citation: Bradley KE, Cook C, Reinke EK, Vinson EN, Mather RC 3rd, Riboh J, Lassiter T, Wittstein JR. Comparison of the accuracy of telehealth examination versus clinical examination in the detection of shoulder pathology. J Shoulder Elbow Surg. 2021 May;30(5):1042-1052. doi: 10.1016/j.jse.2020.08.016. Epub 2020 Aug 29.
